I think it would still come out to a car being worth it, because you'd need to factor in time you are losing going to and from the rental place. In anything, time is always the most valuable, even if you are doing nothing because doing nothing can be more beneficial than constantly going back to a car dealership. I think my ultimate point is it would be way to difficult for one person to figure this out. And can definitely not be dumbed down to an arithmetic equation. Would need to generate a lot of random data and figure out the constraints for each data point. Looks interesting, but I doubt anyone cares enough to figure out what likely has an obvious answer.

Well if we're getting technical, you're probably going to want to run a simulation to figure out your personal odds of the wrecking the car and at what point it negate resale. The resale would also be based on a perfect scenario of getting an ideal amount of money back.

I had neighbors that had two kids that no one could tell me who the fuck the parents were. The kids were nice, one was 6 and the other 10. Everyone night you could smell pot and cigarette smoke coming out the windows and there was loud aggressive rap music constantly playing. There was a revolving group of around 12 tenants (none actually payed rent) and most were drug dealers and a couple were trannie prostitutes. Fights were regular and so was domestic violence. Child services seemed to not really give and shit and the police were useless. I eventually got them by bugging the wards councilman and going through housing court.
All I could think about was how fucked up it was that these kids will change from nice kids to shitty kids by the time they are 12 or 14. When I lived in Louisiana, I would see the same thing happen to white kids in the trailor parks or deep rural areas. The major difference there was steroids.

Age of Chaos aoc.pandapub.com port 4000 RP is non-existant but sometimes done sarcastically There's no one that would probably take any sort of payment
Basically you level to 90 (which is pretty quick) and you multiclass and get your spread ready for the labyrinth which is 13 gates you get through and you are cut off from the world (It is uniquely challenging but all agree it is coded wonderfully and most miss being in it when they get out because of the unique gear). When you finish you transform into one of the 4 ancient races (each AR has for subclasses that are uniquely powerful) and then you level up 180 to make it Hero, that's when you can start taking on the harder content or fight for control in one of the three war zones.

Age of Chaos aoc.pandapub.com port 4000. Heavily modded circle mud. Been around since 96 I believe? There are four monk classes actually: spring, autumn, summer, and winter. Two major differences among the 4 monk classes which are which tattoos they can get and what spells/skills they get. Notable skills, but not a complete list by any means: Spring: Access to the haste tattoo, gets the absorb spell (can absorb incoming spells and sometimes regens mana from them), harmony (a druid heal that is arguebly one of the best heals in the game) Summer: Almost all tattoos are extremely heavy on damage, access to the reflection spell (like absorb but has a chance to reflect the spell back at the caster), wall of fire (extremely annoying pvp spell) Autumn: I think these tattoos suck but luckily they are optional, there is one that gives an extra 1/2 attack, gets the clone spell (awesome spell, basically you get a clone of yourself to group with which is very useful), get the reflection and slow spell and also mimic which allows you mimic spell that someone else can cast if they are in the room. Arguebly gets the best spells Winter: I've never played winter so I can't comment on the usefulness of their tattoos, the body one looks kind of overpowered (-60 armor class, +4 hitroll, endure element), gets ward which is basically a timeout and no one can do anything about it. I think only assholes play winter.
As with all classes they get access to two ancient knowledges through questing. Whirlwind kick (the only non magical AoE in the game and you can use it while blind which is hilarious when you win a pvp match with it). Fists of fury: this is actually brand new and replaced the old one that no one used so I have no idea what it does. I think it's just a giant buff to damage, hitroll, mana, and there a chance on hit to do some extra damage thingy.
The mud is in a lull as it always is in the summer and when fall kicks off people will trickle in. Really you will find that you need no one in the game once you get going. I've been playing off and on for 20 years and there are still zones I don't know.
